awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Bridging the in vitro - in vivo gap through generation of an enhanced microenvironment model for biologically accurate nanomaterial evaluation
awd_abstract_narration:
CBET - 1650960 
PI: Kristen K. Comfort

Nanomaterials (NMs) hold tremendous potential to improve quality of life through applications spanning everyday consumer products to biomedical therapeutics. This surge in NM utilization has resulted in significant degrees of NM waste and increased rates of human exposure, generating the need to ensure the safety of NM-based applications. As NM behavior is dependent upon local environmental factors, this creates a challenge for standard cell-based assessment to produce reliable data, as they lack physiological accuracy. This work strives to overcome these limitations by transforming a standard cellular model into one more representative of a human system, thereby developing an environment more representative of real world exposure scenarios. Through utilization of this enhanced model for NM safety assessments, we will be able to accurately characterize NM behavior and resultant bioresponses accurately and efficiently.

The objective of this CAREER research project is to design, create, and validate an enhanced microenvironment model (EMM) for biologically accurate evaluation of nanomaterial behavior and impact. To accomplish this, the PI proposes to construct and implement the EMM which has the advantages of cell-based systems, while incorporating the key physiological elements. These elements include: 1) a multiple cellular compartment model; 2) dynamic flow connecting all cellular compartments; 3) a inclusion of a circulating immune line; and 4) a scaffold to promote 3D cellular growth. The EMM will be spiked with silver NMs (AgNMs) followed by evaluation and characterization of nanomaterial behavior, pharmacokinetic profiles, inflammatory and mutagenic responses and cellular stress. Analyses of these endpoints will enable validation of the EMM.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Nanomaterials (NMs) hold tremendous potential to improve quality of life through applications spanning everyday consumer products to biomedical therapeutics. This surge in NM utilization has resulted in significant degrees of NM waste and increased rates of human exposure, generating the need to ensure the safety of NM-based applications. The goal of this work was to develop a cell-based model that contained characteristics of human models, including dynamic flow and multiple cell lines, in order to develop an enhanced safety screening mechanism for NMs. This work successfully generated and optimized a 2-dimensional system that contained cellular components of lung, liver, kidney, and macrophages that were all connected via flowing fluid and acted as a single unit.

Following its establishment, this model was challenged with several silver nanoparticles with varying size and surface coatings, in order to elucidate the influence of these physical properties. Cellular-NM interaction studies determined that the presence of fluid dynamics greatly impacted the deposition of smaller particles and that initially the majority of particles were internalized by the first compartment (lung), but over time there was a more even distribution of NM particles throughout the entire experimental system. These results demonstrated that NM localization within a living organism will be dependent on exposure mechanism, duration of exposure, and physicochemical properties of the NMs themselves. This study did help confirm that the tracking of NMs throughout a system is a complex, fluid problem.

Next, the biological responses to the silver NMs was monitored following exposure in both a traditional cell model and the one implemented in this work. When comparing the cytokine and stress responses in the A549/U937 co-cultures, it was shown that the addition of fluid dynamics significantly reduced the AgNM-dependent bioeffects. These results are in alignment with the deposition data. Looking at toxicity and stress within each cellular compartment, the lung model experienced the greatest degree of intracellular stress. This augmented toxicity profile in the first exposed compartment aligns with the greater NM internalization versus the latter compartments which are associated with less AgNM interactions.

This work also had the significant impact of supporting the leaky pipeline of female participation and interest in STEM fields. This work supported numerous female and underrepresented students in gaining laboratory skills and learning about the vocation of research. These students and the principal investigator shared their love for science with a local day care (K-5) and brought hands on experiments to summer camps for these school aged children. These children also had the chance to interact with college students and ask questions about STEM majors. The principal investigator also sought to share her expertise with both graduate students and junior faculty through the development of professional development series to help them progress their research careers.

 


Last Modified: 08/02/2023
Modified by: Kristen Krupa
